words.def: See five on three.
words.name: 2-man advantage

words.def: See odd man rush.
words.name: 2-on-1

words.def: See odd man rush.
words.name: 3-on-2

words.def: In the National Hockey League, a regular season game between two teams who are close to each other in the standings and in the same division or conference. The teams fighting for position have the opportunity to win a game while assuring that their opponent loses, thus putting four standings points (two for each team) into play.
words.name: 4-point game

words.def: See five on three.
words.name: 5-on-3

words.def: See five on four.
words.name: 5-on-4

words.def: See full strength.
words.name: 5-on-5

words.def: The opposing team's end of the ice; extends from the blue line to the end boards.[1]
words.name: Attacking zone

words.def: A slang term used to describe an assist.
words.name: Apple

words.def: Attributed to up to two players of the scoring team who shot, passed or deflected the puck towards the scoring teammate.
words.name: Assist

words.def: A pass or shot that is taken from the backside of the blade of the stick.
words.name: Backhand

words.def: Rushing back to the defensive zone in response to an opposing team's attack.
words.name: Backchecking

words.def: A long looping turn instead of a more energetic stop and start to reverse direction while skating.
words.name: (The) Big Skate

words.def: The puck.
words.name: Biscuit

words.def: To put the puck in the net (to score a goal).
words.name: Biscuit in the basket

words.def: The rectangular pad that a goaltender wears on the stick-holding hand. (See waffle pad.)
words.name: Blocker

words.def: When a player falls to the ice for no apparent reason other than losing their footing.
words.name: Blow a tire

words.def: The lines separating the attacking/defending zones from the neutral zone.[1]
words.name: Blue line

words.def: A defenseman
words.name: Blueliner

words.def: Checking a defenseless player in the back, causing them to violently fall/impact into the boards. This typically leads to the face/head of the unaware player to hit first, causing greater chance of injury. Usually a penalty.[2]
words.name: Boarding

words.def: Glass walls that surround the playing surface.[1]
words.name: Boards

words.def: Using the hip or body to knock an opponent, sometimes against the boards or to the ice. Illegal in the women's game.
words.name: Body checking

words.def: When a player has possession of the puck and there are no defenders other than the goalie between him and the opposing goal.
words.name: Breakaway

words.def: When a goal is scored that strikes the underside of the top of the net, resulting in the goaltender's water bottle being dislodged or knocked off.
words.name: Bottle Rocket/Bottle Knocker

words.def: A style of goaltending wherein the goalie tends to drop to their knees to cover the lower half of the net with his or her leg pads.
words.name: Butterfly

words.def: The act of jabbing an opponent with the knob of their stick. A major plus a game misconduct penalty.[3]
words.name: Butt-ending

words.def: When the puck hits the crossbar and goes in the net. Also called Bar South.
words.name: Bar Down

words.def: Short for ankle bender, a derogatory term for a player who bends their ankles when skating.
words.name: Bender

words.def: A method used to start or restart play in informal hockey or shinny, played without a referee. The puck is placed between two opposing players. The players tap the flat sides of their sticks three times and then go for the puck.
words.name: Bully

words.def: A goal that is scored just before a period expires. The puck must completely cross the goal line before the clock reads 0.00.
words.name: Buzzer beater

words.def: Metal grid that attaches to the front of a helmet to protect the face; occasionally also refers to the goal.
words.name: Cage

words.def: The webbed glove that the goaltender wears on the hand opposite the stick. (Also known as the trapper.)
words.name: Catcher or Catching glove

words.def: A forward position whose primary zone of play is the middle of the ice.
words.name: Centre (or Center)

words.def: Substituting a player from the bench during live play, i.e. not at a faceoff.
words.name: Change on the fly

words.def: The act of taking more than three strides while delivering a body check or leaving their feet to deliver a hit. A penalty.[4]
words.name: Charging

words.def: A hit where the primary contact is made to an opponent's head. A major or match penalty in the NHL if such a hit is made from a lateral or blind side position.[5] In other leagues and organizations, any check to the head can be a minor or major penalty, often including an automatic misconduct or game misconduct penalty.
words.name: Check to the head

words.def: The act of hitting an opponent from the back when they are unaware the hit is coming. A penalty.[6]
words.name: Checking from behind

words.def: When a player stays near their opponent's defensive zone waiting for an outlet pass in order to receive a breakaway. Also called loafing.
words.name: Cherry picking

words.def: Teeth.
words.name: Chiclets

words.def: Hitting an opponent below the knees. A penalty.[7]
words.name: Clipping

words.def: When both teams are assessed an equal amount of penalties at the same time, usually on the same play or incident.
words.name: Coincidental penalties

words.def: Players head with full steam to the front of the net, usually with intentions of finding a rebound or loose puck. Also known as crashing the crease.
words.name: Crashing the net

words.def: See goal crease.
words.name: Crease

words.def: The act of checking an opponent with the shaft of the stick held in both hands. A penalty.[8]
words.name: Cross-checking

words.def: An offensive strategy that moves the puck along the boards in the offensive zone to create a scoring chance by making defenders tired or moving them out of position.
words.name: Cycling

words.def: Defenceman.
words.name: D-man

words.def: The boards, referred to when a player caroms the puck off the boards to clear the puck of their defensive zone or to execute a pass.
words.name: Dasher

words.def: (alternately spelled "defenseman" in the U.S.) One of two players that are positioned further back on the ice than the forwards.
words.name: Defenceman

words.def: a player in the act of defending against an opposing attack (not necessarily a defenceman).
words.name: Defender

words.def: The defending team's zone; extends from the blue line to the end boards.[1]
words.name: Defensive zone

words.def: When a player handles the puck or himself in such a manner to fool the opponent into moving out of position, allowing the player to get past. Originated from the word decoy.
words.name: Deke

words.def: Deliberately causing a stoppage of play; player is penalized with a minor penalty.
words.name: Delay of game

words.def: If a player enters the attacking zone ahead of the puck but does not touch it, the play is offside but no whistle is blown immediately, thus creating a delayed offside. When all players from the offside team leave their offensive zone and go into the neutral zone the linesman cancels the offside infraction. Conversely, if the offending team touches the puck before leaving their offensive zone the whistle is blown for the offside infraction.
words.name: Delayed offside

words.def: When a penalty is called, the referee will raise his or her arm to indicate that one is being called, but if the team who committed the infraction is not in control of the puck, no whistle will be blown until a player from the offending team controls the puck. In this situation the other team will usually exchange their goalie for an extra skater to increase their chances of scoring before the penalty is called.
words.name: Delayed penalty

words.def: An official waits to blow his whistle, usually due to a delayed offside or delayed penalty call.
words.name: Delayed whistle

words.def: When a player embellishes contact made against him in order to entice the referee into calling a penalty against the opposition; however sometimes this ends up in a "unsportsmanlike conduct" penalty being called against the embellishing player.
words.name: Dive

words.def: Some minor penalties, which are 2 minute penalties, may be assessed an additional 2 minutes (4 minutes total), if they are especially flagrant or injurious. A high sticking infraction that draws visible blood will usually be given a double minor penalty.
words.name: Double minor penalty

words.def: When a player passes the puck behind himself to a teammate.
words.name: Drop pass

words.def: When one or more players toss their gloves to the ice in preparation for, or to instigate, a fight. Play is whistled 'dead' until the fight is finished, and the players involved will usually incur a five-minute major penalty each.
words.name: Dropping the gloves

words.def: An offensive strategy used to get the puck over the opposing team's blue line and into the corners where players can race to get it, thereby moving the play into the attacking zone.
words.name: Dump and chase

words.def: A derogatory term for a player who always sits on the bench. The reason they are called dusters is because they "collect dust".
words.name: Duster

words.def: When a player does a series of dekes in a row to get around the opposing players.
words.name: Dangle

words.def: The act of using an extended elbow or forearm to make contact with an opponent. A penalty.[9]
words.name: Elbowing

words.def: A goal scored when the opposing goalie is not on the ice.
words.name: Empty net goal

words.def: A player quick to fight who defends his teammates against violent members of the other team.
words.name: Enforcer

words.def: Teams have an equal number of players (not necessarily their full complement of five) on the ice. See also Full strength.
words.name: Even strength

words.def: A player who has been substituted for the team's goaltender on the ice.
words.name: Extra attacker

words.def: The method used to begin play at the beginning of a period or after a stoppage of play. The two teams line up in opposition to each other. One player from each team attempts to gain control of the puck after it is dropped by an official between their sticks onto a face-off spot on the ice.[10]
words.name: Faceoff

words.def: A centre whose primary skill is winning faceoffs but (generally) provides very little else. (e.g. Yanic Perreault or Manny Malhotra)
words.name: Faceoff specialist

words.def: One of nine painted circles on the ice where a faceoff may occur. Two in each attacking/defending zone, two each near the corners of the neutral zone, and one at centre ice.[1]
words.name: Faceoff spot

words.def: Intentionally rubbing the open palm of a glove in an opponent's face to annoy them.
words.name: Face wash

words.def: When two or more players punch each other repeatedly. A major penalty, and results in a game misconduct in many leagues.[11]
words.name: Fighting

words.def: A strap inside the back of the jersey that loops through the belt, so that the jersey may not be pulled over a player's head during a fight.
words.name: Fight strap

words.def: (also called a two-man advantage) is when one team has had two players sent to the penalty box. This leaves the opponent with five skaters (i.e., not including the goaltender) to penalized team's three.
words.name: Five on three

words.def: (Also called a one-man advantage) When a team is short one player due to a penalty being incurred.
words.name: Five on four

words.def: See full strength.
words.name: Five on five

words.def: The gap between a goaltender's legs.
words.name: Five-hole

words.def: A goalie prone to going down on the ice to stop pucks. The opposite of a 'Stand Up' goalie.
words.name: Flopper

words.def: A term for long, flowing hair, popular among hockey players.
words.name: Flow

words.def: Checking in the offensive zone in order to gain control of the puck and set up a scoring opportunity.
words.name: Forechecking

words.def: The act of trapping the puck so it cannot be played.
words.name: Freezing the puck

words.def: When both teams have five skaters and one goaltender on the ice.
words.name: Full strength

words.def: A penalty that results in a player being ejected from the game. For statistical purposes, a player receiving a game misconduct is often credited with 10 or 20 penalty minutes
words.name: Game Misconduct

words.def: Space between the opponent and the puck.
words.name: Gap

words.def: A goal
words.name: Geno

words.def: When the puck goes over the goal line in front of the net.
words.name: Goal

words.def: An area of the ice that extends from the goal line in front of the net, often shaped like a semicircle and painted in a different colour.[1]
words.name: Goal crease

words.def: An off-ice official who signals when a goal has been scored, usually by turning a red light on above the net.[12]
words.name: Goal judge

words.def: The line that extents from the post to the boards and if the puck crosses the line in front of the net it is a goal.
words.name: Goal line

words.def: When the puck touches the goal line but does not cross it.
words.name: Goal line save

words.def: A selfish player who stands near the goal awaiting a pass from team mates so he can score and get all the glory while they do the work.
words.name: Goal suck

words.def: A player, aka "goalie," who plays in & around the goal (net), whose job it is to make "saves," i.e., prevent the other team from making goals, by stopping the puck from crossing the goal line.
words.name: Goaltender

words.def: A general term for either an enforcer or a pest, depending on the situation.
words.name: Goon

words.def: A Gordie Howe hat trick is when one player scores a goal, notches an assist and gets into a fight all in the same game (a natural Gordie Howe hat trick occurs when a player does all three in one period).: :
words.name: Gordie Howe hat trick

words.def: Hockey grinder A player valued more for hard work and checking skills, especially along the boards, than scoring ability, who often sets up goal opportunities for offensive players.
words.name: Grinder

words.def: A fourth line player who sits on the bench where the forwards and defensemen split.
words.name: Grocery Stick

words.def: A game misconduct penalty for gross unsportsmanlike conduct. Obsolete.
words.name: Gross Misconduct

words.def: see slashing
words.name: Hack

words.def: The act of passing the puck using one's hand. This is legal inside a team's defensive zone, but illegal in the neutral zone and attacking zone, even if the pass originates from another zone.
words.name: Hand pass

words.def: The straight lines from the faceoff circles in front of both nets. Used to line up faceoffs.[1]
words.name: Hash marks

words.def: When one player scores three goals in one game. Fans will honor the player by throwing their hats onto the ice.
words.name: Hat-trick

words.def: The act of deliberately hitting an opponent or directing the puck into the net when leading with one's head. Headbutting an opponent is a penalty,[13] but headbutting the puck into the net results in no goal.
words.name: Head-butting

words.def: A quick tilt of the head in one direction, followed by a quick move in the opposite direction to fool a defending opponent.
words.name: Head fake

words.def: An uninjured player on the roster who does not dress for a game.[14] Only 20 players (22 in international competition) are allowed to dress for a game, players who are not going to play are considered scratches.
words.name: Healthy scratch

words.def: (i) (high-sticking) The act of hitting a player in the head or shoulders with a stick. A penalty (a single minor if no blood is drawn; a double minor if blood is drawn).[15]
words.name: High stick

words.def: (ii) Contacting the puck with a stick that is raised above the shoulders. If the puck is subsequently contacted again by the offending player or a teammate before an opponent touches it, the play is blown dead. A goal scored as a result of a puck being contacted by an attacking player's stick raised above the crossbar shall be disallowed.[15]
words.name: High stick

words.def: Using the hip to knock an opponent against the boards or to the ice.
words.name: Hip check

words.def: a body check that "removes the opposing player from the puck."[16]
words.name: Hit

words.def: The act of impeding an opponent by grabbing onto them. A penalty.[17]
words.name: Holding

words.def: The act of grabbing an opponent's stick. A penalty.
words.name: Holding the stick

words.def: The ability to make the last line change and having your own fans there for moral support.
words.name: Home-ice advantage

words.def: The act of impeding an opponent by placing the blade of a stick into their body. A penalty.[18]
words.name: Hooking

words.def: A very fast slap shot.[19]
words.name: Howitzer

words.def: Icing occurs when a player shoots the puck across both the center red line and the opposing team's goal line without the puck going into the net or being able to be touched by an opposing player in their neutral or defensive zones. When icing occurs, a linesman stops play. Play is resumed with a faceoff in the defending zone of the team that committed the infraction. In the NHL and many professional leagues, icing can be negated if a player from the team committing the icing touches the puck before a defender, in which case play continues (the linesman nearest the puck will indicate this with a "washout" signal). In many amateur leagues, the no-touch icing rule is used, meaning play stops as soon as the puck crosses the goal line. The NHL adopted a rule where the team that committed the infraction is unable to make a line change during the stoppage to discourage teams from icing the puck to "get a whistle" and change lines; this change has been adopted by many pro and high-level amateur leagues, but not all.
words.name: Icing

words.def: A vehicle that reconditions ice before play and between periods of a game to smooth out and clean the ice for optimal glide of both puck and skate. Many may know this from the developer and brand name, Zamboni.
words.name: Ice Resurfacer

words.def: The act of impeding an opponent who does not control the puck. A penalty.[20]
words.name: Interference

words.def: A strategy used by a team defending against a five-on-three advantage. The two defencemen, a forward, and the goaltender align themselves in a diamond shape so that imaginary lines drawn through the two defencemen and through the forward and goaltender form the shape of a cross. This is usually a highly defensive strategy, designed to kill off a penalty as safely as possible.
words.name: Iron cross

words.def: A jill is a simple device used to protect the pelvic area of a female ice hockey player.
words.name: Jill

words.def: A jock is a simple device used to protect the testicles of a male ice hockey player.
words.name: Jock

words.def: (i) The act of propelling the puck using the skates. A goal may not be scored by kicking a puck into the opposing team's net.[21]
words.name: Kicking

words.def: The act of making contact with an opposing player when leading an outstretched knee. A penalty.[22]
words.name: Kneeing

words.def: See Winger.
words.name: Left wing

words.def: The left wing lock is a defensive ice hockey strategy similar to the neutral zone trap. In the most basic form, once puck possession changes, the left wing moves back in line with the defensemen. Each defender (including the left winger) play a zone defense and are responsible for a third of the ice each. Since there are normally only two defensemen, this tactic helps to avoid odd man rushes.
words.name: Left wing lock

words.def: To score a goal. A light above the net turns on when a goal is scored.
words.name: Light the Lamp

words.def: To score an own goal, i.e.: when a defensive player scores into his own net.
words.name: Limoges

words.def: A combination of a specific left winger, center, and right winger. Most teams, for the sake of chemistry, maintain specific three-man lines for different situations (first and second lines for scoring, third lines for defensive-oriented grinders, and fourth lines for pests and enforcers). Lines that play together for several years have become famous in their own right (such as the Russian Five and the French Connection).
words.name: Line

words.def: A series of fights involving most, or all, players on the ice at the same time.
words.name: Line brawl

words.def: During play, or after a whistle, a team may choose to switch out their forwards and/or their defensemen, in order to keep their players fresh, or to match certain players against certain opposing players.
words.name: Line Change

words.def: An official responsible for conducting most faceoffs and for calling off-side and icing infractions. Can call some penalties. Usually two linesmen on the ice during a game.[23]
words.name: Linesman

words.def: In the second period, the goaltenders change ends, meaning that the players' bench is closer to the offensive zone rather than the defensive zone. The "long change" can be a factor when a tired line is stuck in the defensive zone and cannot come off due to the increased distance to the bench.
words.name: Long change

words.def: Hitting someone so hard that they fall over.
words.name: Lighting a candle

words.def: When one team is penalized, and one of its players sent to the penalty box, the second team maintains a man advantage for the duration of the penalty (Major penalty) or until a goal is scored (Minor penalty). If two penalties are called on one team there will be a two-man advantage. If more than two penalties are called on one team the man advantage is limited to two men.
words.name: Man advantage

words.def: A five-minute penalty
words.name: Major penalty

words.def: a five-minute penalty that includes automatic expulsion from the game and, depending on the league, possibly subsequent games. Often called for attempts to deliberately injure an opponent, official or fan.
words.name: Match penalty

words.def: also called a "high wrap," or simply the "lacrosse move," the maneuver of lifting the puck with the stick and throwing it under the top corner of the goal, while skating behind the net, while the goaltender protects the bottom corner. Bill Armstrong invented the move, but Mike Legg made it into a permanent sports reel staple while playing for the University of Michigan[24][25][26] Using the Michigan in a full-speed variation, Mikael Granlund scored a goal at the 2011 IIHF World Championship semifinal versus Russia, helping Finland progress into the final.[27][28][29][30][31][32]
words.name: Michigan

words.def: A two-minute penalty.
words.name: Minor penalty

words.def: A penalty where the offending player is ruled off the ice for 10 minutes, but may be substituted for on the ice. See also game misconduct, gross misconduct
words.name: Misconduct

words.def: A shot that wavers in the air when traveling towards the goal, usually used in recognition of a goal that should have been stopped, or a bad shot.
words.name: Muffin

words.def: A player scores three goals in a row without any player from either team scoring a goal in between them. Also used when a player scores three goals in a single period of play.
words.name: Natural hat-trick

words.def: A goalie, see Goaltender.
words.name: Netminder

words.def: Area of the ice between the blue lines[1]
words.name: Neutral zone

words.def: A defensive strategy focused on preventing the opposing team from proceeding with the puck through the neutral zone (the area between both blue lines) and attempting to take the puck from the opposing team.
words.name: Neutral zone trap

words.def: When a team enters the attacking zone and outnumbers the opposing players in the zone.
words.name: Odd-man rush

words.def: See Attacking zone.
words.name: Offensive zone

words.def: A person who regulates game play, either on or off the ice. See also: linesman, referee
words.name: Official

words.def: The act of shooting the puck directly off a pass without playing the puck in any way.
words.name: One-timer

words.def: An extra session of play added on after the full regulation time has concluded in order to resolve a tie. The first team to score in overtime wins the game.
words.name: Overtime

words.def: When a player shoots the puck at the net with the goalie off the ice or out of position.
words.name: Open Net

words.def: The act of a team (usually unintentionally) shooting the puck into their own net instead of their opponent's. For statistical purposes, the last player on the opposing team to touch the puck is awarded the goal.
words.name: Own goal

words.def: The wide portion above the blade of a goalie's stick.
words.name: Paddle

words.def: The area where a player sits to serve the time of a given penalty.[1]
words.name: Penalty box

words.def: See shorthanded. Also refers to lineups, tactics and play by a team during the shorthanded period. Icing is not enforced on a shorthanded team.
words.name: Penalty kill

words.def: A penalty shot is assessed when a defender is in extreme violation of a rule to prevent a scoring opportunity. Examples are tripping a breakaway opponent from behind, the throwing of a stick or use of hands on the puck by a defender other than the goalie. The offensive player is awarded an opportunity to take control of the puck at center ice and skate in on the defending goalie one on one in an attempt to score.
words.name: Penalty shot

words.def: Player with great speed and quickness.
words.name: Pepper pot

words.def: A player known for agitating opposing players, usually through frequent hitting, sometimes of questionable legality.
words.name: Pest

words.def: The goaltender's leg pads.
words.name: Pillows

words.def: (i) A fast player who usually has more assists than goals. A Playmaker has the speed and balance to make plays, and frequently relies on a sniper to finish them.
words.name: Playmaker

words.def: (ii) A player has three assists in one game.
words.name: Playmaker

words.def: The superstitious practice of a hockey player not shaving off his facial hair during the playoffs, consequently growing a beard.
words.name: Playoff beard

words.def: A hockey statistic that can apply to a player or an offensive or defensive line indicating whether they were on the ice when the opposing team scored (a minus) or on the ice when their team scored (a plus). Goals scored when on a power-play or a penalty kill do not count for a player's plus or minus, respectively, unless a goal is scored while the scoring team is shorthanded.
words.name: Plus-minus

words.def: A player in the opponent's end zone at the junction of the blue line with the boards is said to be at the point.
words.name: The point

words.def: Using the stick to poke the puck away from an opponent.
words.name: Poke checking

words.def: A form of outdoor hockey similar to shinny. A fan might state that their team 'looks like they're playing pond hockey' if the players are not displaying the heart or concentration upon the game that their elite professional level demands.
words.name: Pond hockey

words.def: A handshake between opposing players, who line up parallel to each other, at centre ice, after a game. (In the NHL post-game handshakes are usually reserved until the end of a playoff series and are not a normal event during the regular season).
words.name: Post-game handshake

words.def: A power forward is a large, muscular offensive player (6'0" - 6'5", 210 to 240 pounds), with the mobility to track a puck to the corners of the rink, the physical toughness required to dig it out, and the puck-handling skills to get it back to anyone in front of the net.
words.name: Power forward

words.def: A power play occurs when one team has more players on the ice than the other team as a result of penalties assessed to the shorthanded team.
words.name: Power play

words.def: A young female hockey fan, especially one motivated more by a desire to meet the players than by an interest in hockey.
words.name: Puck bunny

words.def: Remove the goalie from the ice in order to temporarily replace him with an extra skater (attacker).
words.name: Pull the goalie

words.def: Generally, an offensive defenceman that plays one of the points on the power play, and is adept at skating and handling the puck.
words.name: Quarterback

words.def: A stoppage in play that occasionally occurs when an on-ice official view of the puck is obstructed while the puck is still moving or playable but the official stops the play with a whistle. The most common example of this is a goaltender appearing to have trapped the puck underneath his catcher, yet the puck is still freely moving and within legal striking distance of the opposing players. The official will whistle the play "dead" with the puck still visible to others. This often draws an unfavorable reaction from hometown crowds when the whistle negates a perceived scoring chance for the home team.
words.name: Quick whistle

words.def: A rebound occurs when the puck bounces off a goalie, a player, or the net (or occasionally, the back boards) after a shot on goal.
words.name: Rebound

words.def: The official in charge of the game. Responsible for maintaining the flow of the game, calling penalties and starting and stopping play. Can be one or two referees on the ice during a game.[33]
words.name: Referee

words.def: The semi-circular area at the red line, beside the scorer's bench, into which a player may not enter when occupied by a referee (during a stoppage of play).[1]
words.name: Referee's crease

words.def: A player confined to the bench (commonly pine) by a coach due to unsatisfactory performance. Also known as benched.
words.name: Riding the pine

words.def: The playing surface[1]
words.name: Rink

words.def: See Winger.
words.name: Right wing

words.def: The act of contacting an opponent with the hand or fist when making a punching motion. A penalty.[34]
words.name: Roughing

words.def: An airborne pass from one player to another. It is called a saucer pass because the puck resembles a flying saucer in mid air. Actually a low lob pass, barely off the ice but high enough to clear a defender's stick blade. Called so because, from the side it is an arc like that of an upturned saucer.
words.name: Saucer pass

words.def: To stop the puck from crossing the goal line, preventing the opposing team from scoring a goal.
words.name: Save

words.def: An attempt or chance for a team or player to score a goal.
words.name: Scoring chance

words.def: A shot that the goaltender cannot see due to other players obscuring it.
words.name: Screened shot

words.def: The long part of the stick that is straight and is held by the player.
words.name: Shaft

words.def: The period of time a player, line or defensive pairing is on the ice before being replaced by another.
words.name: Shift

words.def: A team is said to be shorthanded when they have fewer players on the ice than the opposing team as a result of a penalty or penalties.
words.name: Shorthanded

words.def: The side of the goal closest to the shooter.
words.name: Shortside

words.def: A shot that will enter the goal if it is not stopped by the goaltender. Shots that either hit the side of the net or miss the goal completely do not count as shots on goal, nor do shots that hit a goalpost or crossbar and do not cross the goal line. Similarly, shots that are stopped or otherwise played by the goalie that would not, according to the judgment of the official scorer, have scored are not counted as shots on goal.
words.name: Shot on goal

words.def: See penalty shot. A series of penalty shots by both teams to determine the winning team after a regulation game and overtime period ends in a tie. In the NHL this occurs only during the regular season.
words.name: Shootout

words.def: A player skilled at defensive play.
words.name: Shutdown player

words.def: Two forwards or defensemen working together, fundamentally to stop the opposing team's offense players.
words.name: Shutdown pair

words.def: The penalty box.
words.name: Sin bin

words.def: Any player who is not a goaltender.
words.name: Skater

words.def: A slapshot is a hard shot, usually with a big wind up, wherein the player bends his stick on the ice and allows the energy stored in bending the stick to launch the puck forward.
words.name: Slapshot

words.def: The act of contacting an opponent's body or stick with one's own as a result of a swinging motion. A penalty.[35]
words.name: Slashing

words.def: Sweeping or kicking out a player's skate or tripping them from behind, causing them to fall backwards. A match penalty.[36]
words.name: Slew foot

words.def: The act of jabbing an opponent with the blade of the stick. A double-minor penalty at minimum.[37]
words.name: Spearing

words.def: A long pass to a moving teammate's feet . This causes the teammate to look down and be open to a devastating body check as the teammate receives the puck.
words.name: Suicide pass

words.def: Slot is the area on the hockey rink directly in front of the goaltender between the face-off circles on each side.
words.name: Slot

words.def: When an official is slow to blow his whistle compared to when the whistle would be blown under similar circumstances.
words.name: Slow whistle

words.def: The purpose of the snap shot is to combine the main advantages of the wrist shot (shot accuracy and quick delivery) and the slap shot (puck speed). Unlike a slap shot, there is no backswing windup, and very little follow through.
words.name: Snap shot

words.def: A player with a powerful, accurate shot skilled at finishing plays.
words.name: Sniper

words.def: a nice goal, with a hard slap shot, wrist shot or snap shot. Backhand goals and deflections are not considered snipes.
words.name: Snipe

words.def: A phrase coined by sportscaster Danny Gallivan to describe a player completing several tight circles with the puck fully under control of his stick, eluding pursuing opponents who cannot keep up or intercept the player. Currently banned in shootouts in the NHL.
words.name: Spin-o-rama

words.def: When an offensive player confuses or outmaneuvers two defensemen in order to get between them.
words.name: Split the D

words.def: A save wherein the goaltender drops to one side and makes the save with his leg pads stacked horizontally atop one another.
words.name: Stack the pads

words.def: A goalie who plays extremely well and keeps his team from losing when they have not played well is said to have stood on his head.
words.name: Stand on his head

words.def: A goalie that often stays on their skates when a player shoots, as opposed to a butterfly goalie.
words.name: Standup goalie

words.def: A defenseman who plays very defensively. He doesn't skate with the puck toward the offensive zone very often but will look to pass first. Usually the last player to leave his defensive zone.
words.name: Stay-at-home defenseman

words.def: Using the stick to interfere with an opponent's stick.
words.name: Stick checking

words.def: The act of controlling the puck with one's stick, especially while maneuvering through opponents.
words.name: Stickhandling

words.def: When a goal is scored, and the light behind the goaltender is lit up, it is said that the goalie got 'sunburned.' Also used when a goaltender has allowed too many goals (i.e. Our goaltender is getting sunburned tonight).
words.name: Sunburn

words.def: The act of returning to the neutral zone after a delayed offside is signaled by the linesman.
words.name: Tag up

words.def: Dragging the puck along the ice with the end (toe) of the stick blade on the ice as opposed to pushing with the bottom edge.
words.name: Toe drag

words.def: The upper area of the goal, just below the crossbar and above the goaltender's shoulders. Also known colloquially as "where momma hides the cookies," a phrase popularized by announcer Rick Jeanneret.
words.name: Top shelf

words.def: Also called the "neutral zone trap", is a defensive-style hockey strategy in which a team loads up the neutral zone with players so that the opposing team has a difficult time crossing the blue line and gaining the zone.
words.name: Trap

words.def: In the NHL, the trapezoidal area behind the goal line and net where the goaltender may touch the puck. A minor penalty (delay of game) is assessed if the goaltender plays the puck behind the goal line outside of the trapezoid.[1]
words.name: Trapezoid

words.def: See Catching glove.
words.name: Trapper

words.def: The act of knocking an opponent down by taking their feet out from under them using a stick or part of the body. A penalty.[38]
words.name: Tripping

words.def: Coined by Don Cherry, the trolley tracks are two 'lanes' in the neutral zone, located midway between the center face-off dot and the boards, spanning from blue-line to blue-line. They are named this due to the common occurrence of a forward receiving a pass from his defense-man during breakout, and then getting completely demolished by an opposing player, usually because they are still looking back at where the pass had originated. This pass is often referred to as a suicide pass. It can be blamed on either the defense-man for setting up such an obvious pass, or the player receiving the pass for not keeping their head up.
words.name: Trolley tracks

words.def: The area on both ends of a bench where the edge of the glass is padded and meets the boards at a right angle. Players have been checked into the turnbuckles causing serious injury. The NHL has replaced this with rounded corners as a safer alternative.
words.name: Turnbuckle

words.def: Another name for a hockey stick.
words.name: Twig

words.def: A forward who handles the defensive aspects of the game as well as the offensive aspects.
words.name: Two-way forward

words.def: when a player throws his stick, usually to another player when that player's stick breaks.
words.name: Throwing his stick

words.def: An off-ice official who reviews a goal by video instant replay.[39]
words.name: Video goal judge

words.def: The goalie's blocker. This term stemmed from the visual appearance of the blocker in the pre-modern ice hockey equipment era (also refer to waffle-boarding).
words.name: Waffle

words.def: A quick save with the goalie's blocker, usually a sideways-sweeping motion. Play-by-play announcer Mike Emrick often uses the term in his broadcasts.
words.name: Waffle-boarding

words.def: In the NHL, an office in Toronto headquarters where games are viewed and reviewed.
words.name: War room

words.def: Typically referred to when there is time and space to skate with the puck, sometimes is said to tell someone to skate faster.
words.name: Wheel

words.def: The area immediately at a player's feet and in line with the player's shoulders, which is the optimum puck location for a player to get the most power from a slapshot.
words.name: Wheelhouse

words.def: A team may, during play or after a whistle, choose to switch out their forwards or defenseman. A wholesale change is when all 5 players (3 forwards and 2 defenseman) are changed at the same time. (See Line Change).
words.name: Wholesale Change

words.def: A winger is a forward position of a player whose primary zone of play on the ice is along the outer playing area. A right winger is responsible for the right-hand side of the ice and a left winger is responsible for the left-hand side.
words.name: Winger

words.def: Scoring from behind the net.
words.name: Wrap around

words.def: A type of shot that involves using arm muscles (especially those in the wrist and forearm) to propel a puck forward from the open-faced, concave part of the blade of a hockey stick.
words.name: Wrist shot

words.def: A popular brand of ice resurfacer (see above).
words.name: Zamboni

words.def: Another word for referee.
words.name: Zebra

words.def: One of three areas of the ice as divided by the blue lines. See attacking zone, neutral zone or defensive zone
words.name: Zone
